net.philsprojects.service
Class ServicePool<E>

java.lang.Object
  net.philsprojects.service.ServicePool<E>
Type Parameters:
E - The event type.
All Implemented Interfaces:
EventHandler<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
TaskServicePool
public class ServicePool<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements EventHandler<E>

A manager of services that handles events by delegating them to a pool of services. The pool can be manipulated explicitly or its manipulated automatically adjusting its Services whenever certain things are triggered by adding an event. Adding an event can trigger the allocation and deallocation of the services, none of these will block the thread which added the event which triggered it, but it will take a brief amount of time. Pool properties are not synchronized with the pool, therefore changes while the pool is started may not be immediate. The pool properties preferrably should be setup before the pool is started, or atleast only modified by one thread at a time.

Author:
Philip Diffenderfer

ServicePool

Method Detail

addEvent

public boolean addEvent(E event)
Adds an event to the pool to be handled by a service. Adding events will not cause contention among threads invoking this simultaneously unless threads must be allocated or deallocated.

Specified by:
addEvent in interface EventHandler<E>
Parameters:
event - The event to add to the pool to be handled by a service.
Returns:
True if the event could be added to the pool, false if this pool is not accepting or this pool cannot handle anymore events.

allocate

public int allocate(int desired)
Allocates the requested number of services. If the number of services requested exceeds the number of maximum possible services the pool will be filled to its maximum size.

Parameters:
desired - The number of services to add to the pool.
Returns:
The number of services added to the pool.

deallocate

public int deallocate(int desired)
Deallocates the requested number of services. If the number of services requested exceeds the number of minimum possible services the pool will be emptied to its minimum size.

Parameters:
desired - The number of services to remove from the pool.
Returns:
The number of services removed from the pool.

start

public void start()
Starts this pool by filling it with its initial set of services.

stop

public void stop()
Stops this pool without waiting for all pending events to be performed but blocks until all services have stopped.

stop

public void stop(boolean wait)
Stops this pool without waiting for all pending events to be performed and optionally blocks until all services have stopped.

Parameters:
wait - Whether this should wait for the services to stop.

stop

public void stop(boolean wait,
                 long timeout)
Stops this pool without waiting for all pending events to be performed and optionally blocks a maximum amount of time for all services to stop.

Parameters:
wait - Whether this should wait for the services to stop.
timeout - The maximum amount of time to wait in milliseconds.

stop

public void stop(ServiceInterrupt interrupt,
                 boolean wait,
                 long timeout)
Stops this pool and optionally waits for all events to be processed and optionally blocks a maximum amount of time for all services to stop.

Parameters:
interrupt - The interruption type. This dictates whether the services must finish handling the events before they stop.
wait - Whether this should wait for the services to stop.
timeout - The maximum amount of time to wait in milliseconds.

isUnderflow

public boolean isUnderflow()
Returns whether this pool has more events that it can handle with its current number of services.

Returns:
True if this pool could use more services, otherwise false.

isOverflow

public boolean isOverflow()
Returns whether this pool has less events than it should for the number of services that exist in the pool. This also factors in the last time services were allocated in order to avoid overactive deallocation.

Returns:
True if this pool could do without servics, otherwise false.

isRunning

public boolean isRunning()
Returns whether this pool is accepting events and has a set of services.

Returns:
True if the pool is accepting, otherwise false.

isStopped

public boolean isStopped()
Returns whether this pool has stopped accepting events and has no services.

Returns:
True if the pool is not accepting, otherwise false.

Returns the maximum number of services that can exist in the pool. This is not thread safe, therefore values returned may be out of date.

getLastAllocateTime

public long getLastAllocateTime()
Returns the last time services were allocated for the pool.

Returns:
The last allocation in milliseconds since the Unix Epoch.

getWaitingEvents

public int getWaitingEvents()
Returns the approximate number of events currently waiting to be handled by one of the services in the pool. This is not thread safe, therefore values returned may be out of date.

Returns:
The number of events not handled yet.

getServiceCount

public int getServiceCount()
Returns the number of services currently in this pool. This is not thread safe, therefore values returned may be out of date.

Returns:

getEventQueue

public BlockableQueue<E> getEventQueue()
Returns the queue of events where the services in the pool poll from. This should not be directly manipulated, unexpected results will occur. A common use for accessing this queue is when the pool has stopped and there are remaining events that must be discarded or explicitly handled.

Returns:
The reference to the queue of events.

getListeners

public Notifier<ServicePoolListener<E>> getListeners()
Returns the notifier which manages the listeners to events in the pool. ServicePoolListeners can be directly added and removed to the notifier. Avoid invoking the methods of the proxy object in the notifier since it may notify the listeners falsely when an event has not actually occurred with the pool.

Returns:
The reference to the ServicePoolListener notifier.
